BE11:20am

Conviviality issued a profit warning yesterday afternoon which was both hugely disappointing for shareholders and also ourselves post the issue of our recent note (22nd February) somewhat ironically entitled ‘Giving the benefit of the doubt’. The note followed the interim results presentation and subsequent meetings with management. What is most concerning for us is the causes and materiality of the 20% downgrade to FY2018F EBITDA expectations. Management highlight a forecasting error alongside lower than expected margins in January and February 2018, both relating to the Conviviality Direct division. We have downgraded our profit and dividend forecasts for FY2018F and FY2019F, which post the share price decline of 59% yesterday leaves the stock trading on a current year PER of 7x. We believe value remains in the business in the medium term but the question is: Can it be delivered by management or a potential suitor? We downgrade our Buy recommendation to HOLD.

#REF! @Soundbuy, questions have to be asked of Auditors. Is all the work being done by fresh out of ACA accountants? Are they looking into the financial software being used and how to check process?
OnYourRight Since leaving uni 20+yrs ago the only people with careers are the teachers and the ones who moved/stayed in London.
BE11:21am

Yeah, it's caught a few people on the hop, this one.

Stateless @BE I know this is not exactly centre topic, but any comments on the Aviva Prefs moves - 30% down
Mouselet what do you mean by 'career' ... does moving every five years to a different software engineering job with a higher salary count?
Pseudonym Actually policing is good too, and doesn't require any of that learnin' they do at uni.
steeplejack Non-Execs at Inmarsat we’re buying stock last Dec and today the company announced that they will cut annual dividend payments by two thirds
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Maybe, for example, be a bit cautious with the buy advice in this morning's Investors' Chronicle: https://www.invest...-has-room-to-grow/

#REF! @OnYourRight I think in Finance all roads lead to London. Not sure one can automatically port that experience to other industries. Tech a good example with firms looking to low cost in country locations, like Belfast (whilst the money burn start-ups are still all about ShoreDitch)
BE11:23am

Investec incoming.

Ethelred Inmarsat?
BE11:23am

The two reasons given for the profit warning are:
1) £5.2m is due to a material error in the financial forecast for the Conviviality Direct business; and
2) While Conviviality’s sales and orders have held up, margins have softened across January and February and
management assume this weakness continues for the rest of the current financial year ie. to the end of April. This is
equivalent to a c.£9m profit hit, which we estimate implies c110bp off 2H18 gross margin of c.13.2%.
 Management also says there has been no material weakness in demand and that the previously announced cost saving
actions remain on track, with £6m of cost synergies guided to in FY18. We understand there was a sales discipline issue
within Conviviality Direct, with no consistent approach to listing fees and promotional offer. This resulted in too much margin
being given away. This has highlighted process and control issues in the business, which management believes it has
addressed and the recent organisation restructuring/completion of the ERM system rollout should help to focus the business
more clearly on profitability rather than sales, we understand.
 Management has confirmed it is still comfortable with its £150m year-end net debt guidance given at 1H18 results, despite
the c.£15m EBITDA downgrade suggested. We estimate this would take the net debt/EBITDA ratio (on a covenant basis) up
to 1.8x which is still comfortably below the debt covenant of 2.5x.
Forecasts/TP/Recommendation placed under review
 Management will give a pre-close update on 27 March, where we hope to get more clarity on the issues. Given a number of
unanswered questions currently, such as where the £5.2m error falls within the forecast and how long it will take to reset the
margins, we place our forecast/TP/Recommendation under review.

BE11:31am

Citi's Take — Inmarsat reported 4Q EBITDA (ex Ligado) of $151.5m, 3.1% ahead of company consensus, driven by strong Aviation and Government margins partly offset by misses at Maritime and Enterprise. Revenue of $321.6m (ex Ligado) was 2.0% ahead of consensus, but declined 1.2% yoy partly due to positive one-off at Government segment last year. The annual dividend from 2018 is being cut by around two-thirds, saving c.$150m pa post the scrip option (assuming the 14% scrip uptake at the interim). Otherwise, the outlook commentary looks broadly in line with consensus. We think the dividend change was largely anticipated by the market.

red BoE cannot raise just because ecb and fed are hawkish, doesnt work like that even if this wish it so.

Implications — This was a solid enough set of results compared to expectations, with better growth at Maritime, VSAT adds not too far off the 3Q pace, and Aviation margin well ahead of expectations. The rebasing of the dividend to 20 cents, flat until FCF recovers sufficiently, should have dealt decisively with that overhang

FATDAZ @Miss piggy easing bias may have been withdrawn but was clear admission that QE could be extended and or increased if Inflation deviates and that's what it has been doing so look for an extension beyond sept 2018 IMHO

Revenue, excluding Ligado, unchanged at $1,300m to $1,500m. This compares to MS at MS $1,361mn and Cons $1,343mn. However, the comments around the Government division are cautious (headwinds persisting, Boeing contract going back to normalised levels, no repeat of exceptional revenues, lumpy), which suggests that consensus 2019 expectations of 5% revenue growth could be too high. There is also a new comment saying that management target “mid-single” digit revenue growth on average over the next 5 years. Consensus is for +8% in 2019.

So, if I'm reading this right, Aviva flagged at results that it can cancel the prefs but hasn't made a final decision yet?

red @Miss Piggybrexit reality not yet driving sterling. brexit hope is. the switch gets flicked between oct this year and march the next.
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Explainer yesterday from Peel Hunt, which says the Aviva decision will set a precedent.

red the other thing is its difficult to embark on a hike cycle while wage growth still below inflation.
BE11:36am

Prefs can be cancelled at par value plus accrued interest through a court approval of a reduction in capital, subject to a shareholder vote.

BE11:37am

Aviva states that no definite decision has been taken yet. It is however clear that as part of the group’s capital management and optimisation plans the preference shares are expensive (they carry a coupon varying from 7.875% to 8.875% with total (non-tax deductible) interest costs of £38m pa). More importantly, these securities are a) not recognized by Moody’s & S&P and, b) will not receive any capital recognition under the Solvency II model from 2026. Hence, there is an incentive for Ordinary shareholders to approve any proposal to cancel these preference shares.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Around £250m worth of preference shares (at par value) are issued by the General Accident subsidiary of which there is only one ordinary shareholder owning 100% of the Ordinary shares: Aviva. As a sole Ordinary Shareholder, Aviva is rationally to vote in favour of a capital reduction through a resolution to cancel preference shares; we believe this would most likely pass.

Miss Piggy @red: carney talks about the speed limit of the economy being lower than normal because of reduced productivity. So won;t take much nominal wage growth to trigger action.
BE11:38am

At the Aviva plc level (£200m preference shares at par value) there are many Ordinary shareholders (4bn shares outstanding) who may vote on any management proposal to cancel the preference shares. The outcome of such a vote, however, is less straightforward as this will depend on a) the number of Ordinary and preference shareholders present at the EGM and, 2) a vote exceeding any predetermined threshold (we understand 75%). Also, preference shareholders at Aviva plc have a ‘four votes per share’ weighting vs a ‘one share one vote’ for Ordinary shares. Assuming 100% of Ordinary and Preference shareholders attend, the vote weighting is 83.3% Ordinary shareholders and 16.6% Preference shareholders. The question is how many Ordinary shareholders will decide to turn up and vote. We estimate that 60% of Ordinary shareholders would need to vote in favour of a resolution to cancel the Preference shares for this resolution to pass.

red @Miss Piggydont think we'll get any. if anything it goes other way. at best stays around 2%

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Here's Barclays.

Upaswellasdown morning all. I've followed Gala Coral for years - hats off to the management for everything they've achieved in the past 8 years (i) dealing with overleveraged business (ii) managing out of opco / propco (iii) selling casinos (iv) selling bingo (v) merging with Ladbrokes and now (vi) being acquired by GVC. Maybe they can have a rest now
BE11:48am

Headlined "No alarms and no surprises"

BE11:48am

The GVC statement today should reassure after a rocky three months for the share price. The current trading figure (18% NGR in constant currency growth) looks solid and guidance for higher gross win margins due to mix is a positive. Current trading is very strong and is a key figure today – momentum should continue. With the migration now complete the focus will turn to the LCL deal which we remain positive on. FY17 results will not surprise. Given sports results were bookmaker friendly in Q4, GVC chose to reinvest in marketing (so marketing: NGR was 25% vs. guidance 23-25%). Given the post close guidance it is no surprise that EBITDA was slightly ahead of consensus (EBITDA was £274m, we had £275m and Bloomberg consensus was £272m). EPS €66 vs. Bloomberg cons €0.64. DPS was €0.34 which was in line.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We continue to think that on a proforma basis GVC-LCL looks very cheap, with high growth and we continue to see material upside to cost synergy guidance. We also think that the US provides a free option for GVC should the market start to deregulate in the next few years. We think GVC's US exposure is under-appreciated. We are currently in Las Vegas meeting key stakeholders and agree that GVC is very well placed to benefit from potential US regulation. The shares trade on 16x cal18E P/E, 11.8x EV/EBITDA, 3.5% Dividend Yield, 0.6% Equity FCF Yield but on a proforma basis, GVC is trading on a CY19 PE of just 10-11x and offers 15-17% EPS CAGR.

Miss Piggy I gave a wrong number earlier, apologies, here is the ECB staff macro-economic projections published yesterday. https://www.banque-france.fr/sites/default/files/medias/documents/march-2018-ecb-staff-macroeconomic-projections-for-the-euro-area_2018-03-08.pdf
BE11:49am

And Berenberg.

erlkin rbc ups hugo boss...cautious on burberry.
BE11:49am

GVC represents a solid buying opportunity in gaming, trading at less than 10x P/E and less than 10x EV/EBITDA on 2020E combined numbers (ie including Ladbrokes Coral and when factoring in a good portion of merger synergies). The excellent start to 2018 suggests that top-line evolution could be better than expected, which adds to the appeal of the stock. The Ladbrokes Coral deal has been approved yesterday, and we expect it to bring about higher-than-indicated synergies. This is our top pick in gaming.

11:50 am

2018 will be: i) the second full year after the acquisition of bwin.party; ii) the second full year after the merger of Ladbrokes and Coral; and, iii) the first year of GVC plus Ladbrokes Coral. The result of all this corporate algebra is a business ripe with cost and revenue synergies under the control of a management team which has demonstrated its ability to manage costs and technology integration.

BE11:53am

I mean, you'll only go as fast as the scooter. The skateboard and rollerskates just add layers of instability and extra weight.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Already at the finish line. Our positive case is based on the potential for strong earnings momentum during the integration of the businesses. But New GVC will also have attractive broad exposure to regulating online gambling markets across Europe, Russia, Australia, LatAm and the US, where major changes could be in prospect. In the past few days both William Hill and Paddy Power Betfair have indicated that they will be looking more closely at growth outside their core markets – markets which New GVC is already

BE11:54am

Our 1,200p price target is based on a 10x EV/EBITDA multiple of 2019 EBITDA including £100m synergies so that we reflect them in our valuation. We reiterate our Buy recommendation.

The Board of GKN plc ('GKN') is pleased to announce that GKN has reached agreement with Dana Incorporated ('Dana') on the proposed combination of GKN's Driveline business1 ('GKN Driveline') and Dana (the 'Proposed Transaction') to create Dana plc, a global leader in vehicle drive systems (the 'Combined Group' or 'Dana plc').

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Summary Financial Terms of Proposed Transaction

· GKN's shareholders to receive 47.25% of the fully diluted share capital of Dana plc at completion of the Proposed Transaction ('Completion'). Based on Dana's fully diluted share capital and closing share price as at 8 March 2018 (being the last trading day prior to the release of this announcement) (the 'Last Business Day') of $26.20, this equates to a value of $3.5 billion (£2.5 billion); plus

· GKN will also receive $1.6 billion (£1.2 billion) in cash2 after deducting for the transfer of $1.0 billion (£0.7 billion) of GKN's IAS 19 pension deficit as at 31 December 2017 (net of deferred tax)3 to

the Combined Group.

Therefore, based on the closing share price of Dana as at the Last Business Day of $26.20, the Proposed Transaction values GKN Driveline at a total enterprise value of $6.1 billion (£4.4 billion), equivalent to a 2017 EV / EBITDA multiple of 7.5x.
